H0.text: Biomass energy is the stored chemical energy of trees and other plants.

H1.text: Decomposition energy is the stored chemical energy of trees and other plants.

H2.text: Biocomposte energy is the stored chemical energy of trees and other plants.

H3.text: Byproduct energy is the stored chemical energy of trees and other plants.

A4.text: Biomass is matter from recently living (but now dead) organisms which is used for bioenergy production.

A5.text: Wood residues are by-products from forestry operations or from the wood processing industry.

A6.text: The vast majority of biomass used for bioenergy does come from plants and fecal matter.

A7.text: In the latter context, there are variations in how biomass is defined, e.g., only from plants, from plants and algae, from plants and animals.

A8.text: Wood is the most significant biomass energy source as of 2012 and is usually sourced from a trees cleared for silvicultural reasons or fire prevention.

A9.text: Cow dung can be converted into methane.

A10.text: Sunlight's radiant energy is captured by plants as chemical potential energy in photosynthesis, when carbon dioxide and water (two low-energy compounds) are converted into carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and oxygen.

A11.text: Energy provided through cellular respiration is stored in nutrients such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins by cells.
